body: @AudriusButkevicius What do you think here? This (and some other similar ones) are either leveldb bugs or just random corruption due to whatever weirdness or unclean shutdown of the system, but we probably need to handle it somehow. Since we do pretty much a full database read on startup, that's probably where it will be detected, and at that point we haven't done too much work yet. Should we simply drop and rebuild the database from start?

Now, I drop old database and rebuild new one, so Syncthing looks like starting synchronization.
If leveldb had some bugs or machine had shutdown uncleanly, syncthing should find these corruption and should correct leveldb, I think.
You mean dropping and rebuilding the database on startup always?

> You mean dropping and rebuilding the database on startup always?

No.
Dropping and rebuilding the database is running only once for restore.

issue.title: Possible corruption on the block data
issue.body:
This could be caused by bug in the `table writer` or `block buffer`.

Corruption on the `block buffer` could be caused by  same buffer acquired more than once from buffer pool by two different `block` instance (or probably added to buffer pool more than once?). 

https://gist.github.com/syndtr/a97bef48b12df8181d6b

Recovering the DB doesn't indicate any corruption but the corrupted table may already been deleted.

Could be related to syncthing/syncthing#987.

body: @calmh I would recommend using `leveldb.Recover` instead. Also you could use `errors.IsCorrupted` to differentiate error that caused by corruption.

issue.title: Unresolvable "leveldb/table: corruption on data-block"

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
I have read in other issues that the data corruption problem has been solved in v0.10.7+, but it seems to still exist. I already had it a couple of times now. It started 2 months ago or so. Until now it always helped to just remove the index-folder and restart syncthing. This time, this does not seem to work. I've done that a few times now, but I always get the corruption error at some point.

I'm currently using v0.10.21. There are multiple devices in my "syncthing network", but only 2 of them were connected while the problem occurred and I have removed the index on both. I've uploaded a few of the panic-logs I received. Please tell me if you need more:
- http://pastebin.com/ELq60ZaA
- http://pastebin.com/jJE805qS
- http://pastebin.com/jz3j7e4B

Note also that one of my syncthing instances runs on ARM, the other on x86. The problem only occurred on ARM so far.

I hope you can fix this bug very soon, because this is of course a showstopper since I can't use syncthing at the moment. And I really want to stick to it, because it's the best sync-solution for me, apart from these problems :)

body: I have the same issue, i deleted the whole db (index) it worked for sometime, then same things again after some time.

What is your OS ? My OS Linux Mint 17. 
On Windows I have not encountered this error.

I just had the same issue on Arch Linux x64... no unclean shutdown though, it seems that the daemon crashed before the error appeared (I added a large folder, 62k files, 23GB).
Is there another way to fix this besides using the -reset flag?
